title: 107_hr613
content: The "Character Learning and Student Success Act of 2001" (CLASS Act of 2001) grants funds for developing and promoting character education initiatives. Character education in schools focuses on improving students' character by teaching ethical values and virtues, promoting a compassionate and responsible society. It involves social, emotional, and ethical development through positive character traits in the regular school curriculum. Effective character education boosts students' self-esteem and reduces the risk of negative behaviors. Character education in schools integrates positive ethical character traits into the regular curriculum and culture, increasing students' self-esteem and reducing the risk of harmful behaviors. Schools that incorporate character education foster the development of core ethical values and virtues in students, serving as a model of a responsible community. States and local educational agencies are increasingly promoting character education initiatives to provide effective methodologies and high-quality programs for teachers and schools. Agencies are promoting character education initiatives by providing access to effective methodologies, professional development opportunities, criteria for assessment, and networking opportunities. A central source of information on the activities of States and local educational agencies is becoming increasingly necessary. Information on the effectiveness of Federal, State, and local educational agency initiatives is crucial. The Secretary is authorized to make a single 5-year grant to an eligible organization with expertise in providing comprehensive information on character education policies, initiatives, curricula, and assessment. Membership should represent various individuals and groups involved in character education. The grant recipient must develop initiatives focusing on core ethical values, student motivation, and creating caring school communities. The grant recipient must address core ethical values, student motivation, and create caring school communities. This includes emphasizing leadership, service, teamwork, and involving families and communities in character education. The effectiveness of character education initiatives should be evaluated, including their impact on disciplinary referrals and teacher expectations. The grantee must use funds to disseminate information on quality character education initiatives, professional development models, assessment methods, integration into educational content, and any other relevant topics. The grantee must use funds to provide a searchable database, checklist, and index related to character education initiatives. The grantee must provide a checklist of criteria, an index of websites, and telephone assistance for character education initiatives. They must also submit an annual report detailing their progress and information requests received. The grantee must provide a checklist of criteria, an index of websites, and telephone assistance for character education initiatives. They must also submit an annual report detailing progress, information requests, unmet needs, and future information needs in the field of character education. Additionally, a detailed account of grant fund usage is required. Authorization of appropriations is set at $750,000 for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006. Grant to conduct character education research. Congress finds that states and local educational agencies have received federal funding for character education initiatives in schools, but there are minimal reporting requirements on their impact. The number of schools implementing these initiatives, their success, and the needs of schools already implementing them are unknown. Efforts should be made to assess the extent and effectiveness of character education in schools. Efforts should be made to determine the extent of character education initiatives in schools, their effectiveness, and the use of Federal funds for these initiatives. The Secretary is authorized to grant a 5-year grant to an organization demonstrating expertise in evaluation, research, understanding of character education approaches, experience in developing initiatives, and identifying quality programs. The grant recipient must assess schools' character education initiatives, categorize approaches, and examine funding sources. The grant recipient must assess schools' character education initiatives, categorize approaches, examine funding sources, and evaluate effectiveness. They are required to submit an annual report detailing their research progress, results, and future information needs in the field of character education. The grant recipient must assess schools' character education initiatives, categorize approaches, examine funding sources, and evaluate effectiveness. They are required to submit a detailed report on research results, unmet information needs, and grant fund usage. Authorization of $700,000 for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 is provided. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "eligible organization" as a tax-exempt organization under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code that has submitted a grant application to the Secretary. It also defines "local educational agency" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "local educational agency" is defined under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 as any elementary or secondary school. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education.
